name:
The following is a transcript of a conversation between the two famous neuroscientists Dr. Buzsaki and Dr. Marder. Dr. Buzsaki's primary interests is 'neural syntax', i.e., how segmentation of neural information is organized by the numerous brain rhythms to support cognitive functions. Dr. Marder studies the dynamics of small neuronal networks, and her work was instrumental in demonstrating that neuronal circuits are not 'hard-wired' but can be reconfigured by neuromodulatory neurons and substances to produce a variety of outputs. The two are having a public academic panel discussion about the function of the higher-order-cortex.
-BEGIN TRANSCRIPT-

children.name: Dr. B: 'What is the primary function of the brain?'
Dr. M:'When we take the brain and we dissect it, we find it's got many different pieces and they interact with each other.'
Dr. B: 'What is neuroscience?'

Dr. M:'We study the nervous system. We're trying to understand how neurons and circuits function in the nervous system. So, we study the nervous system, and we study how the brain works. We're studying all aspects of the nervous system, including its structure, its activity, its development, its function, and how it's built.'

Dr. B:'Okay. So, let me take it from here and say something that's not the question, but it's going to be fun because it's an interesting question, right? What is the question that you ask? It's an interesting question because what I have always thought of is a question that you can ask only when you understand the concept of what you're trying to understand and what you're trying do, right?'
Dr. M:'Mm-hmm.'

Dr. B:'So, in order to understand this question, I think I have to think about some conceptual stuff that will give me the conceptual context to be able to understand it, right? So, you know, it's, what, what, where, when, what, in order to get to this question, what kind of a concept would you like to work with?'
Dr. M:'Oh, we're working on this whole concept of "neural syntax," you know? So, let me start with that.'

Dr. B:'Yeah. I'm happy to have you. In fact, the reason I'm asking is, is because of the work that you do on syntactic aspects of neural syntax. What is the, what is the neural syntax, which is syntactic in that it's a language that has syntax, right? And what, what does that mean?'

Dr. M:'Okay, and so, we've been very, very fortunate in being able to do experimental work in the nervous system, particularly in my field. And we know that we're studying the nervous system and it's important to realize that it is a network. The nervous system consists of neurons that are acting as units, neurons that are acting together. And the neurons in the nervous system that we study are neurons that are firing together because neurons fire in a different time frame.'
Dr. B:'So what the question is, is whether these neurons are connected to each other in such a manner that they can communicate with each other.'
Dr. M:'We study brain function.'
Dr. B:'Do you have a question, or do you have a question for me?'
Dr. M:'A question for you.'
Dr. M:'What is neuroscience?'  I: 'It's like asking, what is sociology, right?'
Dr. B:'Yeah.'  I: 'In some cases it takes about 20 years.'
Dr. M:'Oh, right.'
Dr. B:'But what should we be asking, what should we be looking for, and what are the things that you would like to know more about?'
Dr. M:'I know, why don't you ask me.'
Dr. B:'You will be the best witness.'
Dr. M:'Ok.'
Dr. B:'So what are we? What is a brain? What is a cell?'
Dr. M:'Yes, yes. I am.'
Dr. B:'So how did you get started as a neuroscientist?'

Dr. M:'When I was in college my adviser, he was doing research in a very prestigious institute. I was studying zoology and I took a course in molecular biology. He was doing experiments on cells. And then he suggested we take a course in neuroscience. So, when I was in college I thought there are neurons and there are neurons. There's the neurons in the eye, the neurons in the brain. But then we were taught there were the circuits that made all the neurons work together.'

Dr. B:'Yeah. You know, there's a funny story in neuroscience that always amazes me. It's the beginning of a story. There's no shortage of good neuroscientists. I mean, there are many smart people in the world who are interested in the brain and are willing to study it. But only a very small fraction of neuroscientists is good. And there are others who are mediocre. And there are the really good ones, like you and Marder.'
Dr. M:'You mean the people who are really interested in thinking about how the brain works.'
Dr. B:'Exactly.'

Dr. B:'Sure, but there are many other neuroscientists, like myself, who are much more interested in trying to understand the brain, which is a more practical goal. There are so many interesting things out there to be discovered. But the brain is an essential problem that is really hard to solve. It is a complex system, with a hundred billion neurons in the human brain, each with its own set of rules and dynamics that cannot be understood easily without understanding their interactions.'
Dr. M:'Yeah.'

Dr. B:'Well, I am an idiot in math and physics, and I know nothing about computers. And, to me, the brain is an unsolved mystery. But, I'm really interested in the language of cells. And so it makes sense that I would go and spend my time trying to figure out the rules that the brain uses to make sure that we can understand the rules that it uses to make the brain work.'
Dr. B:'That's a very good point. So, it took you 20 years to make your first major discovery that you made this year, right?'

Dr. M:'You know when I first started graduate school when I started graduate school I was in biology I had taken all of my courses in biology. I had taken molecular biology, immunology, neuroscience. I was interested in neuroscience. And I had thought that this was a course that was going to involve neuroscience. And then we took our first neuroscience course and we studied circuit dynamics and then we went out and did our first experiments on circuit dynamics.'
Dr. B:'What is the primary goal of neuroscience?'
Dr. M:'What is your primary goal in neuroscience?'
Dr. B:'I think a good way to start is to say what kind of questions we are trying to answer. And then we can go from there and move our way up.'
Dr. M:'Right.'

Dr. B:'So, let's go back to the beginning and start off with the most interesting questions: What are we asking? How should we look at this? And then we can start to move our way up the hierarchy of questions that science takes us through.'

Dr. M:'Ok, well, let's say that there are two things going on here: one is how people think about what's important in the brain, and secondly how people think about their brains. So there's some biological components and there's some psychological component that are important to people, and these two things are different, and they kind of feed into each other.'
Dr. B:'But how are we going to understand the brain and its functions without understanding these important things about what are these things in the brain, what is the mind?'
Dr. B:'Yes, so that's why there are people who talk about the brain from a philosophical point of view and the brain from a neuroscientific point of view.'
Dr. M:'And you talk about neural syntax.'

Dr. B:'So in the brain, there are so many things that are important, from language syntax, how we think about the things that are important in the brain and the brain that are important in a way that other animals do not have and do not have. That's the kind of, the kind of syntax that I think is so important is in the brain.'

Dr. M:'Yes, because there are all these connections that you see that come into the brain that aren't necessarily biological, and they're connections that we put there by the brain. So these are not actually biological connections, but are actually connections between neurons that we put there, that we created. So we created synapses that weren't necessary biologically. We did that by our own brains.'

Dr. B:'We have a hundred billion synapses in our brain, and we have to think about how we are going to do this. What are these connections and how are they organized? What is the syntax of the brain? And it will make no sense, to you, but it will make perfect sense to me. And the reason is that in, there are all these synapses and all these neuronal groups, and the connections are all these synaps.'

Dr. M:'There is no syntax, there is no grammar, there is no rule that says where these connections should be. These are connections that we have to think, we have to think up. We have to think about what the connections are, how we think. There are different neurons that might fire different orders of magnitude, so we have to think where we're going to place a connection between these different neurons. So these are really interesting questions.'

Dr. M:'What is neuroscience? Neurons have always been studied, and we're doing better at getting to the fundamentals of understanding the electrical properties of neurons, the electrical properties of networks, how the networks work. What we've realized in the past few decades is that neurons and networks are much more than electrical properties, and we have to pay attention to their synaptic connections and their role in the network.'
Dr. M:'It's the science that studies the brain. It's really the study of how the brain works, how we understand that our neurons are acting as circuits, that we are acting as brains.'
Dr. B:'I see. So there is no neuroscience as such that you are working on?'

Dr. M:'No, because you know all of those brain circuits, those circuits that you look at in terms of a circuit of neurons that can produce behavior, if you like, if you like a neuron that can produce behavior. They are all integrated circuits of neurons, all of these neurons, and these neurons are all connected and all work together, so it's not just this one single neuron that can produce behaviors.'
Dr. B:'Is there something more than circuits and neurons and synapses?'
Dr. M:'I think it's probably more than neurons and synapses.'
Dr. B:'What are the mechanisms that allow for the integration of all those circuits? Or is it still a mystery?'

Dr. M:'Because it's a mystery, but the thing is, you know that is the thing that is the thing, is that it is, the mechanisms that allow integration of all of these cells, these neurons, you know, if you like if you like neurons or neurons that can integrate and work together, neurons that have very different functions, that can work together, because it has to be coordinated, right?'
Dr. M:'What is neuroscience? In a very simple way, neuroscience is understanding how the brain works. In a really complex way, it's understanding how we think.'

Dr. B:'In the simplest possible way, I ask two questions, and then you can ask two questions, which is, what is the function of the brain? And what is the function? Of the brain? So there are two questions, and the answers to both questions are always a little bit different. But it is always the same underlying mechanisms. Because the underlying mechanisms are always the same in the function of the mind and the brain, I don't ask a different question.'

Dr. M:'So, I'm thinking about neurons in the brain and synaptic transmission in the brain. I think it's really interesting, the other day, I'm reading and there's a story about how the stomatogastric nerve in the brain is the only motor neuron that has not been studied.'

Dr. B:'So the reason the stomatoganstric nerve is so special is because the stomatoga?stric nerve is the one that gives rise to the nerve-syntax of the brain, which is very important. Now I have a question for you. How does the brain generate the sequences? The sequences are in the brain, right? I'm sorry, I don't mean to interrupt.'
Dr. M:'I'm glad you did.'
Dr. M:'Neuroscience is understanding how the brain works. How it processes information. How the brain processes information.'

Dr. B:'Okay. The process of information in the brain is pretty simple. There is just nothing there. There is just some electricity, or there is no "stuff" and then there is another process of how the information gets from that electrical activity to its final destination and that is what we call a neural syntax. This is how it works. There is nothing in the brain that generates electrical activity. Nothing that generates a pattern. Everything is generated by the brain.'
Dr. M:'Right. So, when we talk about syntax, we talk about the arrangement of different neurons.'
Dr. B:'Now, this is a big general question, but what is information?'
Dr. M:'I know! I know!'
Dr. M:'We use the term 'information' as a shorthand for how much the brain has to do to determine behavior. It has to be processed. It has to turn into action.'
Dr. B:'How does a brain read that information?'
Dr. M:'Well, the brain has to figure out that information. How it has to read that information.'
Dr. M:'What are you trying to understand?'

Dr. M:'What is neuroscience?  Well, I mean I think you're right that we're in the early days of the neuroscience of understanding how brain circuits work, but at the same time we're in the heyday of the neuroscience. The neuroscience is about studying how the nervous system works as a whole, how its networks of neurons work.'
Dr. B:'What is the difference between the old way and the new way of doing it? Is it a fundamental change, is it a technical change, or what is the change?'

Dr. M:'The change in neuroscience is it's gone from being descriptive and studying what you don't understand to trying to understand what you don't study and studying. And the change in neuroscience is there's been a fundamental shift from being passive about studying what you observe to actually trying to understand how the brain works and how nervous systems work to understanding how neurons work, and how circuits work.'

Dr. B:'Is it just a shift? Or is it a shift? How would you say that you're doing it? What is your research agenda? Do you see a big shift? Or are there small changes, small shifts, medium shifts, or large shifts?  There are multiple shifts. But the biggest shift is that there is now a real shift from being passive to actively investigating how the brain works.'

Dr. M:'Right, so I think the biggest shift is, you know in neuroscience is the shift from simply observing what you do not know how to study to trying to understand how something works. And I think that's been really crucial to the field of neuroscience is to go from just doing random studies to understanding how the brain works, because I've been studying how people work all my life and there's always been this, this thing that you learn.'

Dr. M:'I think I can answer this in a somewhat roundabout way. You see when we came into neuroscience, it was almost by accident that we discovered the brain, I mean there was almost no neuroscience in the world. There were certainly neuroscientists in Italy and Germany and the United States studying invertebrates and the crustaceans and the like. And there was very little done about how human brain circuits worked because you didn't really have access to human brains.'

Dr. B:'Well, when we have access to a human brain and brain diseases, we can learn so much. What's the difference? Is it a technical change? Is it a big difference? Or what is the change? And what is the difference between what you're talking about, the new way and the old way of doing it?'

Dr. M:'The first time we went in we looked at the brain and we saw these networks of neurons, these little cells and so we said 'how is this brain going to work?' And we started asking the question of how brains are formed, how nervous systems work. We started asking the question 'how is information going to be processed?'

Dr. B:'The brain is a complicated system. So there are many brain areas that are complicated and interconnected. What is the strategy to understand how these systems work? How are they organized? Is there a framework?'

Dr. B:'Can you imagine that there's a different kind of future in which neuroscientists are working together to understand how the brain works? And then we'll have a chance to learn how to modify the circuits and the brain so that it will work in a different manner, right? Or is there a vision to be found out? What's the roadmap? What is the roadmap? What's the vision? What's the science roadmap for the future?'

Dr. M:'Well, I think one of the things that we've seen that's interesting that's come to light in recent years is that the brains of many animals are not genetically identical to one another. There is also substantial variability in the neurons that comprise circuits. We also have seen that many, many people have genetic mutations in their neurons that can contribute to neurological disorders.'

Dr. B:'What can neuroscience learn from this new knowledge about how to develop treatments? What are the things that could we work on? What are the questions that we could ask to get started? What are the first questions we need to ask to get started?'

Dr. M:'You know, I think we'll have to take it one day at a time. We're going to have to take it day by day, because that's the reality. Right? So, let's say we just try to understand how it is that you can't understand the brain in a few minutes. Like you can't explain it in a few minutes, how you can think. We'll have to take the lessons that are going to be taught by biology. Right?'

Dr. B:'The thing that I have problems with, right, is the assumption that neuroscience is not capable of understanding how the brain works. It's not capable of understanding what a neuronal network does when it works as a whole in a different way. And that would be the big challenge for neuroscience, is to understand the ways in which a network can work in a fundamentally different manner. So there are two challenges. The first one is to understand what does the brain do when it works as its own entity.'
Dr. M:'It's like understanding how an organism works, right?'

Dr. B:'What is the second challenge for neuroscience? Is to understand how a network can work differently. But in this case it's not the brain that changes, but the network that works differently. Like how a network that can be affected by dopamine can make changes, and then how a network that is affected by dopamine can change the network back to its default state.'
Dr. M:'And we'll see the changes that occur, and we'll understand why some things happen, right?'
Dr. B:'But I'm asking the question, what is neurosciences?'

Dr. M:'Well, if you asked me, like, 'what are the questions that we're gonna ask, what do you wanna know?' I would say there are gonna be questions about how the nervous system can be used for memory, for perception, and then obviously questions about behaviour, you know, like, we want to understand, you know, how behaviour emerges from the underlying processes.'
Dr. M:'What is neuroscience? I don't know what it is, I think it means, really, we understand how the neurons are connected.'
Dr. B:'We do not understand the cells. What is it about the cells that we do not understand? What is the most important question we have to ask today?'

Dr. M:'Well, we understand very, very, very well how the cells function. We know the cells. We know the molecules that are important to their function and we know the electrical properties of the cell. We know that if we change the parameters of their electrical properties, they'll function in a different way, but we don't know how neurons are built.'

Dr. B:'It seems like we have two separate goals. The first goal is to understand the mechanisms of the cells and how they work. And the second goal is to understand how the cells are put together. But I'm just trying to think of other things that we can do, in addition to understanding how neurons work and how they work together.'

Dr. M:'Yes, well, you can. That's the interesting question, what's the role of the cortex, or neurons, or whatever you're going to call it. So, I mean, that's where we're going to be doing a lot of work in the future is understanding how neurons are put together.'

Dr. B:'But before we get to that, I want to try to understand something else. The idea of how neurons interact, how they are put together. That is a big challenge because there are many, many ways to put together a cell. And every, every time, the way that the neuron is built, it comes with a price.'
Dr. M:'Exactly.'

Dr. B:'A price that we pay in our energy consumption. A price that we pay when we have to use our imagination to make up many new names for something. But the price is, the price is the price of progress. So as we go to the bottom-up and bottom-up approaches to the understanding of the brain, the understanding of how neurons are put togete-hr, what I'm asking you is what are the consequences of that for the brain?'
Dr. B:'So, how they connect, so to speak, is not the issue? What is the issue, and that's why it's called science, is how they communicate with each other.'

Dr. M:'The brain has all these many, many neurons that are interacting with each other and that are in the brain. And then we have the muscles that are connected to those neurons. And then you have the skeletal muscles, and then you have the digestive system.'

Dr. B:'And there are various other things. Now, let's say I take a slice of the cortex, say, just at the right time period of the brain activity. What are the different neurons that are in the cortex? And how they interact with each other. And what is the neuronal syntax? And then that will become an answer for neuroscience.'
Dr. B:'So I want to know, how the neurons connect.'
Dr. M:'The neurons connect, okay.'

Dr. B:'That is so vague, it's as if, OK, let me talk about neurons, about how neurons are connected. Do we know how many neurons? Are we talking about two or one or maybe ten? Are we looking for some critical number, and when we get to that number, we'll stop?'
Dr. M:'How are you defining neuroscience?'

Dr. M:'I think most people would answer the same way. It's the understanding of the nervous system, how our bodies work. And we are interested in how our nervous systems work, because there are all kinds of diseases. There are genetic diseases, or genetic malfunctions, and neuropathological diseases. So that is how our brains work. They have malfunction, and it is very important for us to understand that. But also to understand how the brain works.'

Dr. B:'And the difference is what kind of question you ask in this context. So when I'm talking to people in general, I'm talking about the question from the perspective that we will eventually take the time to answer, and that is what is the meaning of our life?'

Dr. M:'That's a very different perspective, because I'm talking about a more immediate practical problem. And it's interesting, because we know about what the brain does, but it's like knowing about what the heart does, or knowing about what the kidneys do. So I think the difference is you're talking about a more direct practical problem, which is how can we fix our brains, or solve our brain problems, but at the same time you're talking about what we're curious about.'

Dr. B:'So, can you expand? There are two approaches that you can take in answering the same problem. One of which is from the perspective of how the brain works, how the neural syntax works. That is a very interesting question. The other is what is the brain for? What is the meaning of the neural syntax? And the way the brain works can also answer those questions.'
Dr. B:'So I'm talking about how to make sense out of our lives, not so much about how to solve the world's problems.'
Dr. B:'So I will try to answer that, because I have a good question, that will let me do that.'

Dr. B:'So when you look at neuroscience as a whole, what's the goal? What's the goal? It's not to understand how the brains work, or how the brain works, but it's to understand how we can get it to work better? And the best way to understand how our brain works, is to ask how we make it to work, in a practical manner. So we're very curious about this.'

Dr. B:'The most difficult thing to do is to take into account the fact that the brain is not just a big pile of neurons, but that it is an extremely complex system and it's been evolving and growing over time. And that's why the complexity of the brain has such a long tail.'

Dr. M:'But the complexity of the system is what is interesting, because it means that we have to study every single neuron, because every neuron is important. Every neuron is important, because it is the part that makes the brain work. For example, the oesophageal neuron is important.'
Dr. B:'Now there is one thing that should be clarified. What is your background? You're a neurosurgeon, and you're a professor of neurosurgery. Where did you train?'

Dr. M:'That is why it is very important to understand the brain and the way that the brain works, because that way we can make general rules. And we can generalize, because as we look at the details we realize that they all work the same way. And it is general rules that will work for all kinds of brain types, or all kinds of different brains. Because we think, well, when I am doing experiments in my laboratory I always think that it is going to be a general rule.'

Dr. B:'What kind of things that would make a general rule? Let me see. And I will tell you, that is not a bad starting point. For example, let's start with the cerebellum, or the basal ganglia or the spinal cord. There are some things that are the same. For example, all parts of the cerebellum do exactly the same thing. And the brainstem, and those are the same, and there are some differences, but there are also similarities.'
Dr. M:'Yes.'
Dr. M:'If we're talking about understanding the brain, what we're doing is really neuroscience'.'

Dr. B:'That's true, but to me what science is always is a process of understanding, of knowing the truth. The process I like is the process of trying to understand how the universe works by building a theory of how it works. So science and neuroscience are different things. I'm sure we both agree that the world is an ocean of theories, each of them trying to explain it to the best of their ability.'

Dr. M:'In neuroscience, we ask: how does the brain work? How do its cells and networks work? There is very strong theory in this area, but it is not well-established, particularly when we're trying to understand how the brain works. You need to understand all the different cells and all the different networks. There are networks of neurons, and each neuron has many connections with other cells. So, you have to understand the brain as a complex network of neurons.'
Dr. M:'How should we answer that question?'

Dr. B:'There is no one good answer. I think the most important question is how much do we understand the brain? Is the brain 50%? 40%? 30%? 20%? 20% is the state where we can say "we have a full understanding." 20% of the brain we can understand today, but how much would that be in two years? 10 years? What will we have to know about the brain to say that we have a full understanding?'
Dr. M:'So a lot of times when people say "what is neuroscience?" the answer is "we don't know yet!'

Dr. B:'I will give you a good example. I will give you a couple of examples, one from my personal research and one from a recent paper. But both are going to be a little bit off the ground and are going to look at a slightly different aspect of the same problem.'

Dr. M:'We have to understand the wiring of the brain first. We have to know how circuits are built, we have to know how neurons are wired. There are neurons that are not even identified as neurons. There are neurons, that you cannot tell apart from other cells. You can not distinguish between cells with electrical coupling. Electrical coupling is a coupling that is mediated through gap junctions. These junctions are between two or more cells that are electrically coupled.'

Dr. B:'Gap junctions are a kind of electrical junctions that are established between cells. There are two types of gap junctions. One type is called 'inhibitory' and these junctions are between inhibitory neurons that are coupled by GABAergic synapses. The second type of gap junctions is called 'excitatory' and these juncles are between excitatory neurons that are coupled in the case of excitatory connections by chemical synapses.'
Dr. M:'That's the other type of electrical junctions, which is excitatory. There are neurons in the brain, that have excitatory connections with each other that are not identified as neurons.'

Dr. B:'What do you think are the conditions to be in to say that we can fully understand the brain? Do you have any example that will say it's been in our grasp for a long time, 20 years, 10 years or even 5 years? Is there any example that will tell us that  "we have a full grasp.'

Dr. M:'I think there are some examples, because we have been trying to study the brain for 20 years, 30 years. We are trying to understand this brain. We are trying and trying and trying. That's all that I'm afraid of, because the brain has got so many different neurons, that it's difficult to find the correct neurons, even with antibodies.'

Dr. B:'The brain has got so much different neurons, that's not so difficult to do, if the problem is to identify them. The problem is not to classify the neurons, but to understand what their jobs are. Is it to generate electric or chemical signals, or it's to make changes in the circuit and not to generate electric or chemical signals, but to change the connections in the circuit.'

Dr. M:'No, the only examples of this are when the systems that we study can be reconfigured, when we can manipulate them in ways that we cannot observe in the natural world. There is a famous example that comes out of work done by some neurophysiologists. When we began to try to understand the function of a single neuron, it became clear that this neuron had many roles. One of those roles is called 'the pacemaker kernel'.'

Dr. B:'A special role of neurons is to generate and to maintain oscillations. In the case of the hippocampus, we can go as far as we want by studying the dynamics of its neurons and we have a really nice understanding of the mechanisms that give rise to oscillations. In contrast, the brain has a huge amount of variability. There is an enormous variability in the dynamics of different types of neurons.'

Dr. M:'What is neuroscience? Well, I've been thinking about the concept of neuroscience for quite a long time, and you know, the idea of a brain as a circuit of interacting neurons, as a collection of circuit neurons and neurons, that are interconnected, and that the neurons, or the neurons that we measure in neuroscience, the neurons we study in neuroscience, are neurons in a circuit.'
Dr. B:'Okay, can you tell us briefly a little bit about the concept of the circuit in the brain?'

Dr. M:'So, we work on the principle that neurons are electrical oscillators, right? So, if you're going to study how a circuit works you need to know how the neurons are interacting with each other. And, so you need to know the synaptic connections, and how the synapses are interacting with the neurons. And then, you know, when you measure the activity of the neurons, the activity of the network, the network activity itself will reveal the actual interaction of the neurons.'

Dr. B:'But what is the definition of the circuit? Is the circuit defined by the boundaries of the neurons? Is the circuit in the middle where you're measuring or the boundaries of the synapses? Is it the neurons that are being monitored? What are the neurons in the brain that you're monitoring? Is it the membrane potential? Is it the spiking output of the neurons? What is the circuit?'

Dr. M:'It's the study of what's really happening inside people's heads. If you're studying people's heads you don't have to study what their brains are doing all the time, but you have to study the brain's activity when they're doing something and you can study that activity, for example, if you are studying the brain of a monkey you can study all kinds of brain activity, and the brain of a person will do all kinds of things.'
Dr. B:'And it's all connected to each other.'
Dr. M:'And it's connected to the brain.'

Dr. B:'Yeah. So what's the problem with the brain and its activity? What's the problem with that, as opposed to say, a neuron or a single molecule? Is it the thing that happens there? Is it the same as that, or is it something else?'
Dr. M:'No, no.'

Dr. B:'But you have to figure out the right way to look at it. And the right way to go about that is by figuring out what is the right way to approach the brain and the brain's activity. If you are interested in the brain's activities, as opposed to the brain's activity, then it would be good to see how it does things. How does it build a cell? How does it build an assembly? How does it read assembly? How does the brain make up a message?'
Dr. M:'Yes.'

Dr. B:'Or, how does it make up a syntactical structure? So that's the kind of thing I'm asking, or I'm trying to figure out is how to proceed. What is the right way? Is it the right way to proceed? What is the right method? Is it the correct way to look at the brain, the brain's activity? What is the correct approach? Do you know what the correct approach is? What is the brain's algorithm?'

Dr. B:'But when you have to deal with some kind of higher order activity, then you have to study it from the brain's point of view, because the brain generates a kind of a syntax which is independent of what it's being generated for. That's why neuroscience was a very good example of a scientific field, which is able to do this, and to relate it to the rest of science and how we all study it.'

Dr. B:'Why is it so difficult to find things that are actually going on in the brains of people? It's very difficult. Dr. B:'But you do understand the difference between how we think about the brain and how we can actually make the brain work.'

Dr. M:'Exactly. And it's about that. We're going to be seeing more and more, you know, about understanding how we use the brain to actually interact with people and how we understand our emotions. So, we're going to be understanding that and understanding the brain. And then understanding how it's being used to do all kinds of amazing things.'
Dr. M:'Oh, of course. Yeah, I know.'
Dr. M:'Yeah, that's one of the points of the talk.'
Dr. B:'What are the major topics? What are the major topics you're going to be discussing?'

Dr. B:'Right, so this is about how we are thinking about the brain and not about how we are making the brain work. So, I want to know, in a world where people like you have made significant discoveries and discoveries about how the brain works, what is the role of neuroscience?'
Dr. M:'You know, so, you know, we started, we started when we were very young because we wanted to understand the brain.'

Dr. M:'Science has a very broad definition and can be many different things. I would define neuroscience as the science that studies the brain and the brain mechanisms that underlie behaviour. So it could be psychology, neuroscience could be neurobiology, neuroscience could be neuroscience as a whole. It could be a neurosurgeon that studies the brain as well.'

Dr. B:'I am going to ask you to list the goals of neuroscience for me. What are the ultimate goals of neuroscience? Do they have some sort of answer? What are the biggest goals of neuroscience? It seems like a lot of work has been going into finding these answers and then putting them into, say, a manifesto or a vision. What are the answers for neuroscientific research? What is the roadmap? Are there some big goals? Where does neuroscience stand?'

Dr. M:'I think the first goal is that we have to start with understanding the brain. There are a lot of fundamental questions we want to answer: What do neurons and their network connectivity look like? How does synaptic transmission occur? What are the underlying mechanisms for how behaviour and cognition occur? What is the role of synaptic strength? And then we want to understand behaviour. How do brains develop? How do brains work? How do brains control behaviour?'

Dr. B:'And do those goals have some sort of overlap or commonalities? What I am asking is whether there are some fundamental goals that would make progress on more than one dimension of neuroscience or whether we can only make progress on one direction at a time.'

Dr. M:'And there are so many different subspecialties within neuroscience. You can look at cell biology. You can look in the realm of neuroscience of cognition. There is neuroscience that looks at the effect of modulation on behaviour and cognition. And then there are neurosurgeons who look at the function of the brain and how the brain controls behaviour. And then you have the neurobiologists who study behaviour from a behavioural perspective, because they want to understand the brain mechanisms underlying behaviour.'

Dr. B:'So if there is some fundamental goal or plan for neuroscience, then let us try to understand the nature of the relationships among these subfields. What would be a good plan? What are the fundamental goals of neuroscience? What are the big goals of neuroscience?'

Dr. M:'It is the study of how neural networks are created, and then how they work. You know I spend most of my time studying the brain and doing basic research, and I do not spend much time in doing neuroscience.'
Dr. B:'So how many papers have you written on the brain, or on how the brain works?'

Dr. M:'Oh gosh I've written dozens. I've written hundreds of papers that I hope that are really important in the way that they advance our understanding of the brain. We now have a lot of knowledge of what the brain is, and we have to try and put that into new forms.'
Dr. B:'What's the most important piece of research that you have worked on?'
Dr. M:'Well, it's hard to say, but we are working on projects and working on the brain, so we do have a lot of papers on the brain and brain circuits.'
Dr. B:'I mean, I know that it is the broad discipline of neuroscience. But, I mean, what really is it?'

Dr. M:'Right. So, if you are a neurobiologist studying how different neurons and brain regions interact, or if you are studying the way the nervous system is reconfigured by neurulation, by neuromodulation, by other processes, the interactions between neurons, or between neurons and receptors for neurons and other kinds of neurotransmitters, that kind of falls in the general field of neuroscience.'
Dr. M:'Well, it's the science of the brain, that's the key.'
Dr. B:'What is the brain? What is a neuron? What is a synapse? What is the brain? Is there a single neuron or a single neuron in the brain? What do neurons look like? What do they do?'
Dr. B:'The brain is made up of the neurons that make it up. What is it? Do you have a general answer?'
Dr. B:'Okay, but what is the definition of the brain?'

Dr. M:'So, the definition of the nervous system is that the nervous system produces sensory perceptions, produces motor reflexes, and also produces autonomic regulation and produces changes in behavior.'

Dr. B:'And, in the brain, it comes to the first level is the cerebrum, the first level is cortex, and the second level is the hippocampus. And this is a level in which the connectivity is organized to produce these changes in behavior.' Dr. M:'Yeah. That's right. And this organization has been the backbone for thinking about the cortex and hippocampus.'
Dr. B:'But what is the organization of these structures?'

Dr. M:'The organization is to produce the same sensory perceptions, the same motor reflexes and changes in behavior, but the organization of the circuits is completely different. The cerebrum is different from the cortex, and the hippocampus is different from the cerebrum.' And we do studies in which we look at the connectivity between neurons and how the circuits work, and we also look at the changes in behavior.'
Dr. M:'It is the study of what is called the nervous system, and the brain.'

Dr. B:'How did we get our first ideas about what a brain is? There was one single neuron in the hippocampus of a mouse that I had to watch carefully to determine whether it would move if it got a piece of meat.'
Dr. M:'So you had to get close enough to see that neuron? How did you know that was a brain?'

Dr. B:'That's how our first ideas about the brain began. Now, I think that we need to get a little older. How did we get our second ideas about the brain? Now, we have a bunch of single cells in the brain, which is called neurons. We just assumed that the activity of the neurons is what we call brain activity, and we just observed the firing patterns of these neurons, and we started to predict things and then we built up from there.'
Dr. M:'You just built up from there? The brain started off with a couple of neurons that fired together?'

Dr. M:'What is neuroscience is to ask what are the properties and processes of the brain, of the nervous system, and the connections between neurons, between neurons and between neurons and other neurons in the brain. We study the brain, but we also study neurons and networks and the brain's interaction with other systems. How the brain is affected by experience, by history, by emotion. How the brain can be influenced by what we call homeostatic mechanisms in other systems.'

Dr. B:'What is the brain's main function? What is the fundamental goal of the brain? What is the brain's most fundamental function? This seems like a pretty serious question, and yet it is pretty easy to answer. And the answer is that the brain does not have a single function. It does not have a simple master function or main goal or fundamental function that is the center of its operations. What it has is a broad family of functions that are very different.'

Dr. M:'Well that's a simple answer, but a very important one. Because there are brain structures that are fundamental and that are important for many different brain functions, and so we look at the different functions that arise from these different brain regions. So if you want to look at the brain, we don't just look at the brain's output, but also its morphology. So the brain is different regions, and many of these regions have different functions.'

Dr. B:'So how do we learn about brain functions? This is another pretty serious question, but you might have an easier time than I have answering it. How do we learn about the functions of the brain? And the answer is very simple: you ask yourself what is the question you want to answer. And this can be a question, "Is the brain the best-known and most well-understood object in the world?'
Dr. B:'What is the goal of neuroscience?'

Dr. M:'The goal of neuroscience is to understand the brain, how its neurons and circuits are affected by the environment, by the history of our nervous system, by the emotional histories of our own lives. Our goal is to understand how the brain is not hard-wired, as it were, but that its properties can be changed by the environment, can be changed by history, and also by neuromodulators, and by all kinds of substances that can be released into the brain.'

Dr. B:'There is a long list of terms in the brain. For example, what is a synapse? And what is a cell? In neuroscience, we need to be able to relate these concepts to each other. For example, I can go to a computer, and I can ask it to give me all of the synapses in the brain. Or I can go to another computer, and I will ask it to give a definition of a cell.'

Dr. M:'This is where neuroscience gets really interesting because it is going to be about brain structure, brain function, how we organize and understand things in the brain, and how the brain changes, as we live in a dynamic world. So, it is going to involve understanding how a neuronal circuit responds to external perturbation, to neuromodulation, to homeostatic regulation of brain function, how brain function changes during development, during learning and during aging.'

Dr. B:'I am going to talk about how these mechanisms are used to form neural syntax and how that syntax is used to represent and store information and communicate between and within neurons and neuronal networks. This is, I think, where neuroscience is going to become really interesting.'

Dr. M:'This is neuroscience, this is about brains, brain circuits, understanding the nervous system how to make computers that can understand the world around them, that can think about things that are important in the world, or learn to read, or play instruments, or sing, or think creatively or understand science, or mathematics, or medicine or law or politics or history.'
Dr. B:'All of this is about how to look at the brain in a way that is productive and interesting and important to understand the fundamental mechanisms of the brain.'
Dr. M:'And then the other big thing of the brain is the behavior and so how the brain is used to support behavior, and then the brain's responses to changes in the environment.'
Dr. B:'And how the brains responses can be predicted from what happens in the environment and how the brain can understand how the environment works.'
Dr. M:'It's all these fundamental principles that you use to develop a deeper understanding of how brains work and how behavior occurs, how behaviour happens.'

Dr. M:'Well, when I think about the field of neuroscience, it's really all about the brain, how the brain works, how all of the neurons work, how the nervous system works, how all neurons are connected, how neurons are different from other neurons.'
Dr. B:'It's been a long time since neuroscience began. How far we've progressed? What is the future of neuroscience?'

Dr. M:'I think there's so many areas where there are still great questions, but we have the technologies now to ask these questions. One of the first questions that came to my mind when I got into neuroscience was: what is the function of neurons? When I first started thinking about this question, which was a classic question, was, do neurons have specific roles? Are neurons kind of, you know, kind of a fixed role, or can they change their properties?'

Dr. B:'But there was no answer. That is, there was no evidence. So I said: "Okay, then what can we do? I'm going to see if, if I can find something where neurons can change their properties." And I found neurons that can change their properties.'
Dr. B:'If you look at it that way, then how can we look at neuroscience?'

Dr. M:'Well, we have known for a long time that neurons have specific electrical properties. You know, in some cases, neurons have certain currents that contribute to their electrical properties. So, you know, we did not discover electrical properties until we started working on how neurons worked in terms of how their membranes responded to depolarizing stimulation. And you know, you go to a neuron that has different properties from all the other neurons.'

Dr. B:'And the difference, right, between all neurons and one neuron or all neurons that contribute to one neuron, is that one neuron has certain properties that contribute to the properties of the population or group of neurons. And it's the differences between all neurons that gives rise to a specific population, right, like the difference between you and I, or, or your brother. Or your sister.'

Dr. M:'But then, you know, the more that we found out about how neurons were, then, like your brother and sister. So, that was like an interesting point for me, right, to have this new level of sophistication, and we had this new technology that allowed us to record from individual neurons. To go from observing properties of all neurons to actually observing properties of individual neurons.'

Dr. B:'What about the difference between what we're talking about today, which is how we segment the neural information into smaller parts, into parts that can be communicated across neurons is that not what I'm asking? Because the brain is also a collection of small groups of neurons. A little group, like a single cell, which is connected to a bigger group. Or a neuron group that contains several interconnected neurons. So it is a collection of groups of cells.'
Dr. M:'And so there are differences between, you know, neurons that can be connected to other neurons and neurons that are in isolation from all other neurons.'

Dr. B:'You know, there are many of us, you know, many neuroscientists, who are not as sophisticated as you, or as the rest of the audience. You know, so there are lots of us who are not yet so sophisticated and we're also interested in the fundamental principles of the brain, just like you, like you know, I'm interested in how the brain can work, how it works.'

Dr. M:'Exactly, exactly. So, that, that, I mean you know, that, you know, and then, and, you know I'm really interested in how, in how, you know, like what are the, what is the dynamics of neural networks. So, the dynamics of neural circuits. What happens when you give a neuron, like, you know, a, a strong electrical stimulus?'

Dr. B:'So how many, how many times can you give your neuron a stimulus and it would still have the same electrical properties? The same properties of all other neurons in the population. What is the threshold for a spiking? The threshold for bursting? What is the threshold between the spikes? Are they all identical? What is the population mean? And are the population mean oscillations? And the population mean is oscillation is the average spiking activity of all neurons in the population?'
Dr. M:'That's right.'

Dr. M:'So, it's that, you know, if we want to understand how people are different, you know, as I'm talking to you today, you know, you might be different from your sister, so, so, so maybe your sister will be different from you, you know, and yet, you know, that's how the population of neurons is, because you see these variations.'

Dr. B:'Yeah. And that, that, that that's where we, where we have to be, is there a way that we can find the cause? We have to understand how they respond, what they do when stimulated, how their membrane responds to depolarizing or hyperpolarizing input. That's where we have to go. And it takes a long time. But the time it takes is not too long. It is not too long for the brain.'

Dr. M:'It is not too long because it's all about how the brain works. So, it is all about understanding how the brain works, and how the brains of animals work. And that, and how the brain of, you know, different people can be different, but yet be consistent.'

Dr. B:'Right. And in fact, my mentor, the, the, the late Endre Grastyn and a couple of people from the New York University School of Medicine were looking at how brain rhythms can be measured, and how we, how we can understand how rhythms are different in different people. I was in school, uh, and I did not take an interest in the brain.'
Dr. M:'Okay.'

Dr. B:'And it turned out that the two are quite similar. They are just as similar, perhaps as similar as the same rhythm is. And yet, uh, it is a different thing. And so I think the more similar brain rhythms are, and the different rhythms are in a way, uh, they're a, a, a, they're a nice way to look at the brain.'
Dr. B:'Yes, but this is the, the difference between single neurons and neurons of the population. So how does that relate to the neuroscience, and in particular, to a neuroscientist?'

Dr. B:'So, when you look into the brain with a new pair of eyes, the world is different. You can see it differently, but the brain is the same kind of thing. It's a mechanism with which the outside world is processed. And in the case of the brain, it's a particular kind of mechanism with which the neuronal syntax is organized to generate particular kinds of outputs. This is what we call function.'
Dr. M:'If you want to know how your brain is wired, you have to go to the neuroanatomy. If you want to understand how your brain works, you have to understand the neurons and the connections.'

Dr. B:'We know how it works, and we know what the parts and connections are. The problem is what we do with those parts and connections. I mean, that's been the challenge of neuroscience since the beginning. What we know about the parts and connections is the same thing we always knew about the mind, which is how it works.'

Dr. M:'A large number of people think of the brain as a big organ, and there are many many important people studying the brain and looking at how the nervous system works. So, neuroscience is the study of neurons, how they work, how their activity depends on intrinsic properties, synaptic interactions, and also interactions with the environment. So, the basic principles that were developed with regard to how the nervous system was put together, how synaptic interactions are responsible for creating the circuits and behaviour that we see.'

Dr. B:'What was your motivation for studying the brain? What are your biggest challenges right now? How do you think about how to move forward? What is your goal? Who is your role model? What would your legacy look like if you could make that happen? What does a good book on neuroscience look like? How much do you think about your future, your legacy? And who is your role model?'
Dr. B:'Why did we choose this field? What is the story of this field, where does it come from?'
Dr. B:'The fundamental laws of the brain are the fundamental laws of the universe.'
Dr. M:'Oh my goodness.'
Dr. B:'There are so many things we are going to talk about today, but first, let me just ask what is the purpose of the research that you are doing?'
Dr. B:'I have a question from a young student that is interested in how the brain works.'

Dr. B:'So there's a hierarchy. The higher order cortex is the most important area of the cerebral cortex because the brain has the highest level of connections with the environment. This area is also connected with each other, but in a different way.'
Dr. M:'You know, you see connections with muscles and joints and muscles and connective tissue and skin and all kinds of tissues that we can measure, we can look at.'

Dr. B:'When we move, what are the important principles for maintaining this relationship between the brain and its sensors and its effectors? What is it that allows us to move our skeletal muscles? Are these the important principles that maintain the stability of the brain? Are these important principles that allow for communication? Is it, or, if not, what are the other important principles that allows for communication?'

Dr. M:'So we have our neurons that are electrically coupled to one another, and then we have the synaptic connection, the chemical synaptic connections. We have electrical coupling to one another and we have chemical synapses. So, there are two kinds of synapses. There are electrical synapses and there are chemical synapses. There is also electrically coupled neurons that are not chemically synaptically coupled. There are electrical-coupled neurons that are not synaptically-coupled.'

Dr. B:'And then we have to look at how neurons communicate, how they synchronize one another. But the communication or the synchrony is very important because these are the processes that are essential for the functioning of neural networks, both within the brain and in the body. And they are also the processes that are also essential for the survival of the organism. So, the question is what is it that allows for the preservation of the connections that are important for the functioning of neurons?'
Dr. M:'The higher order cortex, which is the most important brain region, is also connected with other brain regions. So it's connected with the sensory and motor regions.'

Dr. B:'Are there any areas in the cortex that are not connected with anything else? Are there areas that you like, and maybe you would like to work on, and perhaps they're not connected? What are they connected to?'

Dr. M:'Some of them are not. Some of them are not connected. So, we have some that are connected to each other and some are not. There's some that are connected, and there's some that are not connected to any other areas. So, if you're looking to connect with another part of the brain or connect with another part, you know, you may not be interested in a region that doesn't connect to anything. So that's the way I would think about it.'

Dr. B:'A lot of people talk about the "default state of the brain" and the "default network," but, uh, how much are these ideas really grounded? I mean, how much work is being done in this area? And how do we define the default state? How do we define the network? What is the default state? Is it sleep or awake,? Is it quiet? Is it silent? Is it a particular region of the brain? How is it organized?'

Dr. M:'But there's not a hierarchy in the sense that you can take one small neuron or a small group of neurons, and you can examine their response to a specific stimulus and then determine how they interact with the rest of the brain.'

Dr. B:'What kind of neuroscience is this? What kind of research is it? I mean, what is it? What are we looking at? What are the things that we are looking at? What would be the best way to look at it? What do you see? What do you think is the best way to go about it?'

Dr. M:'Well, first of all, we are looking at neurons, and we are looking at neuron dynamics, and we are interested in how neuron behaviour depends on membrane properties, but also on synaptic interactions. So, neurons that express the same voltage-dependent channel proteins, we don't want them to behave the same way, but we want to understand the underlying properties of each neuron, and to understand the way that synaptic interactions work. So, that is part of the basic principle that we are interested in.'

Dr. B:'How do we get from this point to the implementation of the brain?' How do we get from there to where we are currently with the implementation? What is a path forward? In other words, what are the things we are looking at, and the things that we want to understand? What would be best way to go forward?'
Dr. M:'In other words, how does it work?'
Dr. B:'What is the main goal of neuroscience?'

Dr. M:'Well, you know, you've got to figure out the role that the brain plays in thinking, and learning, and working, and understanding the world. So, there are many different kinds of questions that we would like to answer.'

Dr. B:'In other words, how can we break down the work that neuroscience does into its basic principles? Is there a way of breaking it down into its basic principles, and then, we can work with those and do the rest of the work?'

Dr. M:'I think that's a good way of putting it. I mean, you know, we like to think of ourselves as being able to sort of fit pieces of our work into categories, or groups of work, that we can think of as being somewhat related. So, you know, in the early days of neuroscience there was, you know, there was some sort of a debate on whether you know, was it the kind of right way of going about understanding how the nervous system worked?'
Dr. B:'And, uh, I'm going to give you a little bit of that, but I want to sort of ask you about your work and your views in a little bit more detail.'
Dr. M:'Ok.'

Dr. B:'I'm very much on the side of the early days of science when it was, in fact, very very different to the way we live now, but I'm very much in favor of being able to use new information to refine our understanding of how to do our job.'
Dr. B:'Now, what is a neuron?'
Dr. B:'When is a good time to study the brain? What would you suggest?'
Dr. M:'Well, when it is exciting to be involved in studying brain function.'
Dr. B:'What would be the best place to study the brain?'

Dr. B:'What is an example of a fundamental thing in the brain, and what is the role of the brain in that fundamental thing? Let me give you an example that comes from the area of my interests, which is how brain rhythms can be the mechanism for this process.'

Dr. M:'Sure. So, the principle of the pacemaker kernel, which has to do with the maintenance of stable frequency in the brain, has been studied and studied in many, many different types of animals and different species, and in fact, the pacemaker kernel itself is a very simple, small network of cells, and it does not depend on synaptic interactions to produce its stable period.'
Dr. B:'Okay. What happens when you remove synaptic interactions, and therefore what we see is that the time constant remains the same, but the network becomes unstable and oscillatory.'
Dr. B:'Why is there a need to study the brain? What are the primary goals?'

Dr. M:'The primary goal is to understand how the nervous system functions as it is, the brain is just a very tiny portion of the nervous system, but it is very important, because that's the starting place from where it can all arise.'

Dr. B:'Do you agree with the primary goal, to understand how the brain works? If we're already aware of how the brain works, it would be very convenient to understand how to manipulate those principles and use those as a tool to understand how we can control the brain. It would be very convenient.'

Dr. M:'You should probably think of it as a whole field, with different types of experimental methods that can be used. So you're thinking of things like MRI or other kinds of neuroimaging and biophysical measurements of neurons and things like electrical recording and all of the different kinds of measurements that are possible.'

Dr. B:'That's right. I'm going to start with what I don't know. It's the kind of what I would want to answer in a few minutes. I'm going in a few different directions. One way is to say, 'Well, what is the big question? Is it about what the brain does? How does the brain work? What is the big question?' I think that would be a really good starting point.'
Dr. M:'Yeah.'

Dr. B:'What are the problems and goals of neuroscience today? Do you think that neuroscience has a particular path forward in the next 10, 20, 50 years? Are there particular issues that we should address first? Or are there areas we should avoid because they are not tractable at the moment? Or do you think we should look back and reexamine how we did things in the past?'

Dr. M:'I don't know. I guess you probably think more about where you're going to look rather than what problems there are. So, one thing I'm going to look for is how different systems in the brain work in a biological system, rather than necessarily to try to solve some particular problem. I guess, I know a little bit about the problems of neuroscience.'

Dr. B:'That is indeed a very broad perspective. But in particular, what would you say is neuroscience's fundamental question? And what are the fundamental research questions that are being asked about, say, the next 10 years? What I'm talking about are the questions about what we are trying to find out about the brain. Let me put it more concretely and say that there are at least four questions about the brain that I would like to understand.'

Dr. M:'So I think it's the brain is really what the focus should be on. The brain and its interactions with other parts of the body. Because, as you're saying, we're really thinking about how things work, or how people think about how things work. So, I mean I have the example of our brain.'
Dr. B:'You're trying to list it all so that I can think of it in a bigger context.'

Dr. M:'So, to be honest with you, I think a lot of people who are just thinking about doing neuroscience studies are, they think of it more as a subfield or as a field that is similar to chemistry. And when they get to the biophysical recordings of neurons, they think 'well, I can only use electrophysiological methods.' And it can be. But they often then get excited to think about other kinds of measurements that they wouldn't ordinarily think about doing.'

Dr. B:'It's just like how people are fascinated about the history of the mind and neuroscience, and are excited about doing it. It's a similar kind of curiosity to be honest. But it's, it's, there's a lot to think about. And there's a lot of ways to be able to understand a system. And then the question that's the interesting part of it is, what is the function? What is the brain function? And what is the goal of the brain?'
Dr. M:'Right.'

Dr. B:'But what is the big picture? There are a lot of things that are different. So here are some of them: in chemistry, you can choose which elements are going to make up the composition, but then there are a lot of possibilities that can be done in neuroscience.'

Dr. M:'Well, you can answer that either way, by saying, I study neurons, I study synapses, I study networks. You can study neurons, but you can also study synapses and networks. You can get very different conclusions by doing that. So, the idea is that the brain is more than just cells, neurons, and synapses, and that the brain has to operate in a very rich interplay between those many different components.'

Dr. B:'But how does it work? In particular, when I was in elementary school, I learned that when you send signals into a brain and ask it to respond, it gives you an output. But what if you are not interested in the output? What if you want to understand how the brain handles input? In which case, you would have to look at the response patterns and correlate them to input patterns to see how the brain handles those input patterns.'

Dr. B:'The brain is organized into a hierarchy of interconnected structures in which the components interact with each other. In order to understand how this occurs, it is necessary to understand how the organization of the different layers and layers interacts with each other. This is what I call the neuronal syntax.'
Dr. M:'Yes.'

Dr. B:'I understand this interplay, but I can't explain the why. You understand it, but you don't explain it. So it is the reason why I'm a bit worried, how you can go into the brain with the idea that you have a lot to figure out, and then all you have to figure out is the mechanisms that explain what we see in the brain, or that's not the case.'
Dr. B:'How do you break this down, in the sense of a neuron, for example? Or a synaptic junction? Or a network? And so on?'

Dr. M:'So, a neuron can be a synapse, it can be a network, it can be all of the above. A synapse can be a network. It doesn't have to be. But in general, in general, in all species, a neuron is the most general unit, because a neuron has to be identified before you can study other properties. And that is usually the case, because they have to identify the cells.'

Dr. B:'Let me start with synapses and networks and move to the other parts of the brain. And in the process of learning about the structure of the brain, it may be that you can identify more precisely the parts of the brain that are responsible for the operations that you study.'

Dr. M:'Yeah, that's right. So, you know, it depends. You can study a synapse, for example, that is probably not going to give you insight into the brain. But if you can study a circuit of neurons in the brain, that's going to give you insights into what the brain is doing and how it works. And then you can move to the rest of the brain, and maybe you have a model for the rest of the body.'

Dr. B:'You know, it's interesting, though, in the sense that if you want to be able to understand how the brain works, it's a prerequisite, and I have to say, the understanding of how the brain works. But this is a prerequisite for understanding how the brain works and what it is actually doing. What does it do? What is the brain's job? And what is its output? What is it?'
Dr. M:'I'm asking you because you're saying this is the most important thing, and it's going to help us understand things in the brain.'

Dr. M:'Well, I suppose when I was studying biology, neuroscience was something that I would have to read about in a book somewhere else, but you know, I think in terms of the kind of the underlying science behind what is in our minds, you know, we always knew that you know we didn't know that much about how cells and how the brain worked. We didn't know how neurons worked.'
Dr. B:'So how did you get into neuroscience?'
